Common stockholders are able to vote for the board of directors, on merger decisions, and on the selection of auditors.
Cumulative voting makes it possible for a minority shareholder to have more proportional representation on the board.
The call feature benefits the firm because when the stock's market price is lower than the call price, the firm can call the shares and reissue them later at a higher price.
The dividends of non-cumulative preference shares do not accumulate over time when they are not paid, but dividends for any period must be paid before common shareholders can receive dividends.
Common shares have less risk than preferred shares because the dividend is stable.
Private equity markets are smaller than public markets but are growing rapidly.
Venture capital refers to the capital provided to firms early in their life cycles to fund their development and growth.
In a Management buyout, investors buy all of a firm's equity using debt financing.
Indirect investing in the securities of foreign companies simply refers to buying a foreign firm's securities in foreign markets
Depository receipts (DRs) represent ownership in a foreign firm and are traded in the markets of other countries in the parent company currency.
Global registered shares (GRS) are traded in different currencies on stock exchanges around the world.
Non-cumulative preferred shares have less risk than cumulative preferred shares because they retain the right to receive any missed dividends before any common stock dividends can be paid.
For both common and preferred shares, puttable shares are less risky and callable shares are more risky compared to shares with neither option
Callable shares usually have higher dividend yields than non-callable shares.

Conglomerate discount is based on the idea that investors apply a markdown to the value of a company that operates in multiple unrelated industries, compared to the value a company that has a single industry focus
Leading P/E uses earnings over the most recent 12 months in the denominator.
The amount that's left after the firm has met all its obligations to its other investors is called free cash flow to equity.
P/S ratio is meaningful even for distressed firms, since sales revenue is always positive.
P/S ratios is useful to capture differences in cost structures across companies.
P/E ratios are particularly appropriate for valuing stocks in mature or cyclical industries and start-up companies with no record of earnings.
Price to cash flow is more stable than price to earnings.
Empirical evidence indicates that differences in price to sales are significantly related to differences in long-run average stock returns.
Cash flow is easier for managers to manipulate than earnings.
Dividends are not as risky as the capital appreciation component of total return.
The dividend displacement of earnings concept argues that dividends paid now displace future earnings, which implies a trade-off between current and future cash flows.
Controlling shareholders can also enjoy excessive compensation and other perquisites to the detriment of minority shareholders.
The prior transaction method (PTM) uses transactions data from the stock of the actual subject company and is most appropriate when valuing minority (non controlling) interests.
c) Holding Period Return> Arithmetic Return> Geometric Return
Transaction-related valuations are performed when there is venture capital financing, an IPO, a sale of the firm, bankruptcy, or performance-based managerial compensation.
Multifactor models can have greater explanatory power than the CAPM, which is a single-factor model.
The build up method is a multifactor model that attempts to account for the higher returns generally associated with small-cap stocks.
The betas tell us about the characteristics of the asset being evaluated, and the risk premia tell us how those characteristics are priced in the market.

Beta drift refers to the observed tendency of an estimated beta
 to revert to a value of 1.0 over time.
Country Risk rating model uses a corresponding developed market as a benchmark and add a premium for the emerging market

Country Spread model estimates a regression equation using the equity risk premium for developed countries as the dependent variable and risk ratings (published by Institutional Investor) for those countries as the independent variable.
A public sale of the firm's equity increases its liquidity.
Compliance-related valuations are performed for legal or regulatory reasons and primarily focus on financial reporting and tax issues.
Compliance-related valuations are necessary when selling or financing a firm.
Transaction-related valuations may be required for shareholder suits, damage claims, lost profits claims, or divorce settlements.
Market approach values a firm as the present value of its expected future income.
Asset based approach values a firm using the price multiples based on recent sales of comparable assets.
In a strategic transaction, valuation of the firm is based in part on the perceived synergies with the acquirer's other assets.
A financial transaction assumes no synergies, as when one firm buys another in a dissimilar industry.

The guideline public company method (GPCM) uses price multiples from trade data for public companies, with adjustments to the multiples to account for differences between the subject firm and the comparables
In an efficient market, upon declaration of dividend, stock price increases till the cum-dividend date by the amount of the dividend and regains the original price by the ex-dividend date

How are investment bankers generally compensated under traditional underwriting?
The stockbroker, representing the investment banker, charges a commission to investors.
The leader underwriter in the underwriting syndicate dictates the commission that the other firms must charge so that investors pay for a majority of the underwriting expense.

The Glass-Steagall Act from 1933 separated investment banking and commercial banking all over the world.

The Lincoln Rule in the Dodd-Frank Act from 2010 in the U.S. bars the access of swap dealers to the Federal Reserves discount window.

What does Gary Gorton mean, when he claims that the propagation of the financial crisis from 2007-2008 was due to a run on the repo?
Repo Bank was the largest bank in Europe and it became insolvent because of a bank run.

Repos is the nickname for so-called shadow banks, which are small commercial banks in the U.S. During the financial crisis, many of these small commercial banks had to be rescued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).

Repos, which is short for repurchase agreements, are credit default swaps that protect against losses of Lehman Brothers. After Lehman Rsquo;s collapse on September 15, 2008, there was a run on these contracts.

Repos, which is short for repurchase agreements, are short-term loans between institutional investors that in principle share many similarities with deposits at commercial banks. A loss of confidence in this market led to a run in this market, leading to a withdrawal of funding, which shares qualitative characteristics with a bank run on a commercial bank.
